questions.text: The mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillins via betalactamase is by-
questions.solution:
Betalactamase is enzyme produced by bacteria which will break the penicillin ring.

Penicillin has the "ring" structure in it. It is hexagonal structure.

Altered penicillin binding protein is not the mechanism of bacterial resisitance to penicillin via betalactamase.

Drug efflux is not the mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via betalactamase

Alteration in 50s ribosome is not the mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via betalactamase

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Altered penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) → This is a different mechanism of resistance seen in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae (PRSP), but it does not involve β-lactamase.
  • (Option B) Drug efflux → Some bacteria use efflux pumps to remove antibiotics from the cell, but this is not how β-lactamase works.
  • (Option C) Alteration in 50S ribosome → This is a mechanism of resistance for protein synthesis inhibitors like macrolides, not β-lactam antibiotics.

Key Takeaways:

  • β-lactamase breaks the β-lactam ring, destroying penicillin's structure.
  • Altered PBPs cause resistance in MRSA and PRSP, but not through β-lactamase.
  • Efflux and ribosomal alteration do not play a role in β-lactam resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following is common soil transmitted helminthic infection in India is characterized by eggs in stool shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
This egg is of Trichuris Trichiura. It is plano convex or barrel shaped.Size is around 50-55 micron by 20-25 micron.

They have thick shell and possess a pair of polar plugs at each end. The eggs are unembryonated when passed in stool.

They are brown in colour.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Ascaris → Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are oval, golden-brown, and have a thick, bumpy (mammillated) coat.
  • (Option C) Enterobius → Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) eggs are flat on one side (D-shaped) and smaller.
  • (Option D) Ancylostoma → Hookworm eggs (Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus) are thin-shelled, oval, and segmented inside.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trichuris trichiura eggs are barrel-shaped with polar plugs.
  • Common in India as a soil-transmitted helminth.
  • Differentiate from Ascaris (mammillated), Enterobius (D-shaped), and Ancylostoma (thin-shelled, segmented).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about JE?
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis is found in asia and west pacific, in this disease there is brain swelling.

Japanese encephalitis is virus ( Flavi virus)spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes. It is more common in rural and agricultural areas.

Most cases are mild, rarely it cause serious brain swelling with sudden headache, high fever and disorientation.

Pigs are amplifier host

This virus transmits by Culex vishnui

Vaccination of pigs can control transmission.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Pigs are amplifier hosts → Pigs develop high viremia, allowing mosquito transmission.
  • (Option C) Transmitted by Culex vishnui → Culex vishnui is a major vector of JEV.
  • (Option D) Vaccination of pigs controls transmission → Reducing viremia in pigs helps control spread.

Key Takeaways:

  • Humans are dead-end hosts, not reservoirs.
  • Pigs are amplifier hosts and play a major role in transmission.
  • Culex vishnui is a primary mosquito vector.
  • Vaccination of pigs helps control transmission.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy presents with vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. What is the likely causative organism responsible for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
This case is of Food poisoning. It is caused by many bacteria S aureus, E coli, Salmonella spp., clostridium botulinum, clostridium perfringens.

Incubation period of all bacteria varies.

S aureus has incubation period of 2 - 6 hrs, Bakery items, Pastries, sweets are source of S aureus.

It is caused by preformed enterotoxin. Enterotoxin is heat stable. It is superantigen like toxic shock syndrome toxin. Toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of brain. It acts directly on the autonomic nervous system than on gastro intestinal mucosa.

Salmonella, Clostridium botulinum has incubation period more than 6 hrs.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Salmonella → Incorrect.
    • Causes foodborne gastroenteritis, but incubation period is 6-48 hours (not within 3 hours).
    • Symptoms include fever, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps rather than isolated vomiting.
  • (Option C) Clostridium botulinum → Incorrect.
    • Causes botulism, which has an incubation period of 12-36 hours.
    • Symptoms include flaccid paralysis, diplopia (double vision), and respiratory failure, not just vomiting.
  • (Option D) Clostridium perfringens → Incorrect.
    • Causes food poisoning with watery diarrhea, but incubation is 8-16 hours, not within 3 hours.
    • Vomiting is rare with C. perfringens food poisoning.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rapid-onset (≤6 hours) vomiting → Think Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Heat-stable enterotoxin, commonly found in dairy, bakery items, and meat.
  • Other foodborne illnesses (Salmonella, C. botulinum, C. perfringens) have longer incubation periods.

questions.text: Super antigen is produced by which of the following-
questions.solution:
Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome is caused by one of super antigen produced by Streptococcus pyogenes.

It also produces necrotizing fasciitis, Kawasaki disease, psoriasis and acute rheumatic fever.

Super antigen will stimulate TH1 on large basis. All cytokine will increase.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Clostridium perfringens → Incorrect.
    • Produces alpha toxin (lecithinase), theta toxin, and enterotoxins, but not superantigens.
    • Causes gas gangrene and food poisoning, but does not trigger a cytokine storm.
  • (Option C) Vibrio cholerae → Incorrect.
    • Produces cholera toxin, which activates Gs-protein, leading to massive watery diarrhea.
    • Not a superantigen; instead, it increases cAMP, causing electrolyte loss.
  • (Option D) Staphylococcus epidermidis → Incorrect.
    • A commensal skin bacteria that can cause biofilm-associated infections (e.g., prosthetic valve endocarditis), but does not produce superantigens.

Key Takeaways:

  • Superantigens cause excessive immune activation → Cytokine storm.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes → Streptococcal TSS, necrotizing fasciitis, and scarlet fever.
  • Staphylococcus aureus (not S. epidermidis) also produces superantigens → Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS).

questions.text: In renal transplant recipients, which is the likely organism causing reactivation disease within 1-4 months after surgery?
questions.solution:
CMV is also known as salivary gland virus

CMS is the largest virus among herpes viruses

They are characterised by enlargement of infected cells ( Cytomegalic cells) and intranuclear inclusion.

Once infected person is carrier of CMV

CMV is most common organism causing intra uterine infection.

Diffuse interstitial pneumonia, between 1-6 months after kidney transplantation is caused by CMV.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) → Incorrect.
    • Reactivates in transplant patients but is more associated with Post-Transplant Lymphoproliferative Disorder (PTLD) rather than pneumonia.
  • (Option C) Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) → Incorrect.
    • HSV reactivation occurs earlier (within the first month) and primarily causes mucocutaneous lesions, not pneumonia.
  • (Option D) Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) → Incorrect.
    • VZV reactivation (shingles) can occur in immunocompromised patients but typically presents later with painful vesicular rashes along dermatomes, not interstitial pneumonia.

Key Takeaways:

  • CMV is the most common cause of reactivation disease in renal transplant recipients (1-6 months post-transplant).
  • Presents with interstitial pneumonia, hepatitis, colitis, and graft dysfunction.
  • Histology shows Owl's eye inclusions.

questions.text: A 30 year old man reports four hours after acquiring a clean wound without laceration. He had received TT vaccination 10 year back. What do you advice regarding tetanus prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
As it is clean wound without laceration, Person has taken TT before 10 years.

So as per guideline, he should take single dose of TT

Prevention of tetanus after injury.

All wounds must be thoroughly cleaned soon after injury- Removal of foreign body, soil, dust, necrotic tissue. This procedure abolish anaerobic conditions which favour germination of tetanus spore.

Further management depend on the immune status, type of wound and duration of wound.

A - He had complete course of toxoid or a booster dose within the past 5 years

B - Had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose more than 5 years ago and less than 10 year ago

C - Had a complete course of toxoid or a booster dose more than 10 years ago.

D - Has not had a complete course of toxoid or immunity status is unknow.

All wound surgical toilet

1) Would less than 6 hr old, clean, non penetrating and with negligible tissue damage

  • IF A - nothing more required
  • IF B - Toxoid 1 dose
  • IF C- toxoid 1 dose
  • IF D - Toxoid complete course

2) Other wounds

  • IF A - nothing more required
  • IF B- toxoid 1 dose
  • IF C - Toxoid 1 dose plus human immunoglobulin
  • If D - Toxoid complete course plus human immunoglobulin

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Full course of TT → Incorrect.
    • Full TT course is only needed if the last dose was >10 years ago or if the patient has never been vaccinated.
  • (Option C) 1 dose TT + TIG → Incorrect.
    • Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is only required for high-risk wounds (dirty, deep, or crush injuries) in patients whose last TT dose was more than 10 years ago or unknown.
  • (Option D) No vaccination needed → Incorrect.
    • Since the last dose was 10 years ago, a booster dose is required.

Key Takeaways:

  • Clean minor wound + last TT dose 5-10 years ago → Single booster TT dose required.
  • Dirty wound + last TT dose >10 years ago → TT + TIG.
  • No prophylaxis if last TT dose was within 5 years.

questions.text: DOC for invasive aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Asper fumigates is most common cause of aspergillosis.

It has branching hyphae

Most common disease in human is caused by Otomycosis.

Most effective drug for invasive aspergillosis is Voriconazole.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Amphotericin B → Not the first-line treatment.
    • Used in severe cases or when voriconazole is not available or contraindicated.
    • Liposomal Amphotericin B is preferred over conventional Amphotericin B due to lower nephrotoxicity.
  • (Option C) Posaconazole → Not first-line.
    • Used for prophylaxis in high-risk immunocompromised patients (e.g., neutropenia, post-transplant).
    • Also used for resistant cases of invasive aspergillosis.
  • (Option D) Echinocandins → Not first-line.
    • Includes caspofungin, micafungin, and anidulafungin.
    • Used as salvage therapy for patients intolerant to or not responding to voriconazole.

Key Takeaways:

  • First-line treatment for invasive aspergillosis → Voriconazole.
  • Amphotericin B (liposomal) → Used in severe cases or resistance.
  • Posaconazole → Used for prophylaxis and resistant cases.
  • Echinocandins → Salvage therapy.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide protective immunity to neonate in-
questions.solution:
Maternal antibodies can protect in Diphtheria, Pertussis and Tetanus Not in Polio,

Maternal antibodies to polio may impair the immune response of infants to the polio vaccine.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Diphtheria → Protected by maternal antibodies.
    • IgG antibodies from the mother cross the placenta, providing passive immunity.
    • Newborns are protected for several months, but vaccination is still required.
  • (Option B) Pertussis → Partial protection by maternal antibodies.
    • Maternal IgG offers some protection, but wanes early in infancy.
    • Infants rely on DTaP vaccination for full protection.
  • (Option C) Tetanus → Protected by maternal antibodies.
    • Maternal IgG antibodies protect neonates if the mother is vaccinated.
    • Neonatal tetanus is preventable if the mother receives tetanus toxoid vaccination during pregnancy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Polio is NOT effectively protected by maternal antibodies.
  • Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus have some degree of protection via maternal IgG.
  • Polio vaccination is essential in early infancy due to lack of natural passive immunity.

choices.text: Prophylaxis with erythromycin and diptheria antitoxin
Immunize with booster of diphtheria toxoid

questions.text:
A 5 year old boy presents with sore throat for the last two days.
On examination he has a grayish white pseudomembrane around his tonsils (image shown). Diphtheria is suspected. What prophylactic step should be taken for the 3 years old younger sibling who has received immunization as per the immunization schedule?
questions.solution:
The case is of Diphtheria. Secondary prophylaxis of 3 year old sibling is required. He has receive immunization as per schedule. As per guidelines no any other thing is required.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Prophylaxis with oral erythromycin → Not required
    • Erythromycin prophylaxis is given to close contacts who are unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated.
    • Since the sibling is fully vaccinated, antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed.
  • (Option B) Prophylaxis with erythromycin and diphtheria antitoxin → Not required
    • Diphtheria antitoxin is used only in symptomatic cases.
    • Erythromycin is used for exposed individuals who are at risk (unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated).
    • The sibling is protected by vaccination, so neither erythromycin nor antitoxin is needed.
  • (OPtion D) Immunize with booster of diphtheria toxoid → Not required at this age
    • The routine immunization schedule includes DTaP (Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Pertussis) at 6, 10, and 14 weeks, with a booster at 18 months.
    • A booster is required at 5 years of age, but at 3 years, no additional dose is needed.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fully vaccinated children do not require prophylaxis if exposed to diphtheria.
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis (erythromycin) is for unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated close contacts.
  • Diphtheria antitoxin is only used for symptomatic cases.
  • A booster of diphtheria toxoid is given at 5 years, not at 3 years.

questions.text: Recent influenza A pandemic was due to-
questions.solution:
Influenza is RNA virus. It has segmented RNA. 8 segments are there. Till now many epidemic and pandemic has occurred by various stains H5N1, H1N1 etc

Antigenic shift and antigenic drift occurs in Influenza A virus.

Antigenic shift is major change in antigenic structure and responsible for pandemic.

Antigenic drift is minor change in antigenic structure and responsible for epidemic.

This virus is present in birds and animals ( Swine). That s why it is also known as swine flu.

Recent influenza pandemic was due to H1N1.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) H5N1 → Causes bird flu, not a pandemic
    • H5N1 is highly virulent in birds and can infect humans, but human-to-human transmission is rare.
    • It has not caused a pandemic but has led to localized outbreaks.
  • (Option C) H7N7 → No major pandemic
    • H7N7 is an avian influenza strain that has occasionally infected humans but has not caused a pandemic.
  • (Option D) H3N3 → Seasonal flu strain, not recent pandemic
    • H3N2 is a common seasonal flu strain that has caused epidemics but not recent pandemics.
    • A major H3N2 pandemic occurred in 1968 ("Hong Kong flu").

Key Takeaways:

  • H1N1 caused the 2009 influenza A pandemic (swine flu).
  • Antigenic shift (major change) leads to pandemics, while antigenic drift (minor change) causes seasonal epidemics.
  • H5N1, H7N7, and H3N3 have not caused recent pandemics.

questions.text: Which of the following is category A bioterrorism agent?
questions.solution:
Bioterrorism is new way of war. Here instead of weapons, virus or bacteria are used.

Those virus or bacteria are used which can be transmitted easily from person to person.

They are classified as category A,B and C

Category A agents are considered the highest risk and the highest priority, category B agents are second highest priority.

Category A - Anthrax, Botulism, plague, small pox, tularaemia, viral hemorrhagic fever Spp,

Category B - Brucella, Salmonella, E coli O157: H7

Category C - Nipah virus, Hantavirus, tick borne hemorrhagic fever, west nile fever.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Coxiella → Category B agent
    • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever) is a Category B bioterrorism agent, not Category A.
    • It spreads via aerosolized particles but has a lower fatality rate compared to Category A agents.
  • (Option B) Brucella → Category B agent
    • Brucella spp. (brucellosis) is a Category B agent, as it spreads via contaminated animal products rather than direct person-to-person transmission.
  • (Option C) Nipah virus → Category C agent
    • Nipah virus is classified as Category C because it is less transmissible but could be engineered for bioterrorism.

Key Takeaways:

  • Category A agents (Highest risk):
    • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis)
    • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
    • Smallpox (Variola virus)
    • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
    • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis)
    • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (Ebola, Marburg, Lassa, etc.)
  • Category B (Moderate risk):
    • Brucella, Coxiella burnetii (Q fever), Ricin toxin, Salmonella, E. coli O157:H7
  • Category C (Emerging threats):
    • Nipah virus, Hantavirus, Tick-borne hemorrhagic fever, West Nile virus

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be acquired by traumatic inoculation?
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenkii is caused by thermally dimorphic fungus sporothrix schenckii.

It is naturally found in soil, hay, sphagnum moss, and plants. It usually affects farmers, gardeners and agricultural worker. This fungal disease usually affects the skin although rare forms can affect the lungs, joints, bone and CNS.

Fungus enters through small cuts and abrasion in the skin to cause the infection.

Because roses can spread the disease, it is one of a few diseases referred to as rose thorn or rose gardener's disease.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Blastomyces dermatitidis → Inhalation, NOT traumatic inoculation
    • Causes blastomycosis, a fungal infection acquired via inhalation of spores from soil and decaying wood.
    • Affects the lungs primarily and can disseminate to skin and bones.
  • (Option C) Coccidioides immitis → Inhalation, NOT traumatic inoculation
    • Causes coccidioidomycosis ("Valley Fever"), acquired by inhaling airborne spores from desert soils.
    • Common in Southwestern USA (California, Arizona, Texas).
    • Causes pulmonary infections with potential dissemination.
  • (Option D) Paracoccidioides brasiliensis → Inhalation, NOT traumatic inoculation
    • Causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection endemic to South America.
    • Acquired via inhalation of fungal spores.
    • Primarily affects the lungs with possible mucocutaneous lesions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sporothrix schenckii is the ONLY option associated with traumatic inoculation (via thorns, soil, plant material).
  • Other fungi (Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides) are acquired through inhalation.

questions.text: Shown in the figure is the HBV card test. Which of the following is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B can be diagnosed by many ways, rapid card test, principle is chromatography test.

ELISA is one of method to diagnose hepatitis B inf

PCR is also used for diagnosis of Hepatitis B inf.

Rapid chromatography is easy and cost effective, it has good sensitivity and specificity.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Chemiluminescence → NOT used in HBV card test
    • Chemiluminescence immunoassays (CLIA) detect antigens using enzyme-labeled antibodies that produce light emission upon reaction.
    • Used in automated lab tests, NOT in rapid card tests.
  • (Option C) ELISA → Used for HBV detection, but NOT the principle of card test
    • Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) is a sensitive lab-based method for detecting HBsAg.
    • Requires 96-well microplates, enzyme-linked antibodies, and colorimetric detection.
    • More sensitive than rapid tests, but not the same principle.
  • (Option D) Immunofluorescence → NOT used in HBV rapid tests
    • Uses fluorescent-labeled antibodies to detect antigens under a fluorescence microscope.
    • Used in viral diagnostics, but NOT in rapid card tests.

Key Takeaways:

  • HBV card test uses immunochromatography (lateral flow assay).
  • It is rapid, cost-effective, and detects HBsAg.
  • ELISA, CLIA, and immunofluorescence are lab-based methods, NOT the principle of the card test.

questions.text: Which of the following is the vector for Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Zika virus is transmitted by Aedes mosquitos. Which bite mostly during the day.

Most common symptoms of zika are fever, rash, headache, joint pain, red eye , muscle pain

zika virus can cause birth defects and is linked to Guillain barre syndrome.

Very rarely zika may cause severe disease affecting the brain, causing swelling of the brain or spinal cord or a blood disorder which can result in bleeding

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Culex tritaeniorhynchus → NOT a vector for Zika virus
    • Culex mosquitoes are vectors for Japanese Encephalitis Virus (JEV) and West Nile Virus (WNV).
    • They bite at night, unlike Aedes mosquitoes.
  • (Option C) Phlebotomus papatasi → Transmits Sandfly Fever Virus, NOT Zika
    • Phlebotomus papatasi (sandflies) transmit sandfly fever virus (Pappatasi fever) and Leishmaniasis.
    • They are NOT involved in Zika transmission.
  • (Option D) Anopheles → Transmits Malaria, NOT Zika
    • Anopheles mosquitoes are the primary vectors for malaria (Plasmodium spp.).
    • They are NOT known to transmit Zika virus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Aedes aegypti is the primary vector for Zika virus and also transmits dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever.
  • Zika infection in pregnancy can cause severe birth defects (microcephaly).
  • Culex, Phlebotomus, and Anopheles mosquitoes do NOT transmit Zika virus.

questions.text: Antiseptic property of bleaching powder is due to-
questions.solution:
Bleaching power, a solid combination of chlorine and slaked lime. Introduced in 1799 by Scottish chemist Charles tennant, It is a strong and effective disinfectant, its active sodium hypochlorite is effective in killing bactria, fungi, viruses, including influenza virus, but is easily inactivated by organic material.

Diluted house hold bleach disinfects within 10-60 minutes contact time.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Hypochlorite (OCl-) → Less potent than HOCl
    • While hypochlorite ion (OCl-) is also present in bleaching powder, it is less effective than hypochlorous acid in disinfection.
    • HOCl is 80-100 times more effective than OCl- in killing microbes.
  • (Option C) Chlorine (Cl2) → Not directly responsible for antiseptic action
    • Chlorine gas (Cl2) is used for water purification and industrial disinfection.
    • However, in bleaching powder, its disinfectant action is mainly due to the release of HOCl, not Cl2itself.
  • (Option D) H+ (Protons) → Not involved in disinfection
    • While pH affects the formation of hypochlorous acid (HOCl), H+ ions do not directly contribute to antiseptic properties.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) is the primary antiseptic agent in bleaching powder.
  • HOCl is much more effective than hypochlorite (OCl-) in killing microorganisms.
  • Bleaching powder is widely used for disinfection in water purification, sanitation, and medical applications.

questions.text: A female from a tribal area of Jharkhand reports with fever for last 3 days. Peripheral blood is collected and stained with Giemsa. A diagnosis of malaria is made. The smear is shown in the figure. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Given case is of Malaria. Blood picture shows ring structure. Ring of P vivax and P falciparum are different. Gametocyte are also different in shapes.

In vivax in RBC one ring is seen and Falciparum multiple rings are seen.

VIvax ring is bigger than falciparum ring.

Because gametocyte of P Falciparum is banana shaped. Or sausage shaped with pale blue or pink cytoplasm, large diffuse nuclear,

Macrogamete are - crescentic deep blue cytoplasm, compact nuclear

While p Vivax Microgamate are Spherical, compact pale blue cytoplasm diffuse nucleus

Macrogamate large spherical deep blue cytoplasm

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) P. vivax → Usually a single large ring per RBC
    • P. vivax shows a single ring per RBC, which is larger and more prominent than P. falciparum's multiple small rings.
    • Schüffner's dots (stippling in infected RBCs) are seen in vivax, which are absent in P. falciparum.
    • The gametocytes of P. vivax are round, not crescentic.
  • (Option C) P. malariae → Band form trophozoites
    • P. malariae trophozoites show a characteristic "band form" across the RBC, which is not seen in the given image.
    • The gametocytes of malariae are round, not crescentic.
  • (Option D) P. ovale → Rare and has oval RBCs
    • P. ovale is rare in India.
    • Infected RBCs appear oval-shaped with fimbriated edges, which are not described in the given case.

Key Takeaways:

  • Multiple ring forms per RBC → P. falciparum.
  • Banana-shaped (crescentic) gametocytes → P. falciparum.
  • Schüffner's dots and a single ring form → P. vivax.
  • Band-form trophozoites → P. malariae.
  • Oval RBCs with fimbriated edges → P. ovale.

choices.text: No vaccine needed as exposure has already occurred.

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old close friend is in fear of contracting disease. What advice should be given to her-
questions.solution:
Meningococcal meningitis can spread from one person to other. Because it stays in nasopharynx of person. 

Now in the given case 2 girls in the same class are already diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their friend must get two dose of conjugate vaccine to prevent getting infection.

Incorrect options :

Option A is wrong two dose of polysaccharide vaccine.

Option C is wrong Single dose of meningococcal vaccine. Because meningococcal vaccine has two dose not one.

Option D is wrong, vaccine can help in spreading of infection. No matter exposure has occurred or not, vaccine can always help.

Key Takeaways:

  • Conjugate vaccines (MCV4) are preferred over polysaccharide vaccines (MPSV4).
  • Close contacts of meningococcal meningitis cases require vaccination and antibiotic prophylaxis.
  • Meningococcal conjugate vaccine induces stronger, long-lasting immunity and reduces carriage.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300/cumm presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the figure. On microscopy budding yeasts and pseudo-hyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given is case of opportunistic infection in AIDS. As HIv virus infection progress patients CD4 cell count starts decreasing.

And patient starts having opportunistic infections.

In given case, CD4 cell count is 300/cumm and pt has mucosal lesions in mouth , from microscopy finding it is candida infection.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Oral hairy leukoplakia → Incorrect
    • Caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).
    • Characterized by white, non-scrapable plaques on the lateral tongue (unlike candidiasis, which is scrapable).
    • More common in CD4 count <200/mm³.
  • (Option C) Lichen planus → Incorrect
    • Characterized by Wickham’s striae (fine white lace-like pattern) on the buccal mucosa.
    • Does not show budding yeasts or pseudo-hyphae on microscopy.
  • (Option D) Aphthous ulcer → Incorrect
    • Presents as painful, round ulcers with a red halo and yellowish base.
    • Not associated with budding yeasts or pseudo-hyphae on microscopy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Oral candidiasis is the most common opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS.
  • CD4 count <500/mm³ increases susceptibility to fungal infections like Candidiasis.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of budding yeasts and pseudo-hyphae on microscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Role of fimbriae is adhesions. Fimbriae can have other role as sex pilus, which helps in transfer of genetic material between two bacteria.

Role of flagella is locomotion. It can be monotrichous, peritrichous, Lophotrichous, amphitrichous

LPS is lipopolysaccharide it is present in Gram negative bacteria, it has role in septic shock production.

Mesosome supports respiration and secretion and enhance plasma membrane surface area and enzyme .

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Cytoplasmic membrane → Incorrect
    • The cytoplasmic membrane controls transport of molecules in and out of the bacterial cell.
    • It does not play a direct role in adhesion.
  • (Option B) Mesosomes → Incorrect
    • Mesosomes are infoldings of the plasma membrane.
    • Their proposed functions include respiration, DNA replication, and secretion, not adhesion.
  • (Option D) LPS (Lipopolysaccharide) → Incorrect
    • Found in Gram-negative bacteria, it is a component of the outer membrane.
    • Plays a role in immune evasion and septic shock, but not in adhesion.

Key Takeaways:

  • Fimbriae (pili) are the primary bacterial structures responsible for adhesion.
  • They allow bacteria to attach to host cells and establish infections.
  • LPS and mesosomes serve other functions but do not help in bacterial adhesion.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of donovanosis?
questions.solution:
Donovanosis is also knows granuloma inguinale, it is a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram negative bacterium klebsiella granulomatis ( formerly know as calymmatobacterium granulomatis) .

Sign and symptoms include one or more painless lumps, usually in the genital, anal region or groin. The lump slowly gets larger and then ulcerates. These sores typically bleed easily, have a rolled edge and are beefy red in colour. In some cases the sore has an offensive smell.

Lab diagnosis - IN lab Donovan bodies are seen. They are rod shaped, oval organisms that can be seen in the cytoplasm of mononuclear phagocytes or histiocytes in tissue samples form patients with granuloma inguinale. They appear deep purple when stained with wright’s stain.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) Haemophilus ducreyi → Incorrect
    • Causes Chancroid, a painful genital ulcer with ragged edges and soft base.
    • Unlike Donovanosis, Chancroid is painful and has tender lymphadenopathy.
  • (Option C) Leishmania donovani → Incorrect
    • Causes Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), a systemic disease affecting the spleen, liver, and bone marrow.
    • Does not cause genital ulcers.
  • (Option D) Treponema pallidum → Incorrect
    • Causes Syphilis (a sexually transmitted infection).
    • Primary syphilis presents with a painless, hard chancre, not beefy red ulcers.
    • Secondary syphilis causes systemic symptoms and rashes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Klebsiella granulomatis causes Donovanosis, a painless, progressive genital ulcerative disease.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of Donovan bodies in histiocytes.
  • Differentiated from other STDs like Chancroid (H. ducreyi) and Syphilis (T. pallidum) by ulcer characteristics.

questions.text: Urethritis in males is not caused by-
questions.solution:
H ducreyi is fastidious gram negative coccobacillus bacteria. It causes sexually transmitted disease chancroid, a major cause of genital ulceration in developing countries characterized by painful sores on the genitalia.

It doesn’t cause urethritis. Rest three organism can cause urethritis trichomonas, chlamydia and gonococcus.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) Trichomonas → Incorrect
    • Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that can cause urethritis in males.
    • Symptoms include dysuria, discharge, and urethral irritation.
    • It is more commonly associated with vaginitis in females.
  • (Option C) Chlamydia → Incorrect
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars D-K) is a leading cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU).
    • Symptoms: clear/mucoid discharge, dysuria, urethral discomfort.
    • If untreated, it can lead to epididymitis and infertility.
  • (Option D) Gonococcus → Incorrect
    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonococcal urethritis, the most common bacterial urethritis.
    • Symptoms: purulent (thick, yellow-green) discharge, severe dysuria.
    • Can lead to complications like epididymitis and prostatitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid (painful genital ulcers) but not urethritis.
  • Trichomonas, Chlamydia, and Gonococcus are common causes of urethritis in males.
  • Chlamydia is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU).
  • Gonococcal urethritis is more purulent and symptomatic compared to NGU.

questions.text: The Immunoglobulin structure (dimer) shown in the figure belongs to which class of antibody?
questions.solution:
Ig A exist either as monomer or dimer

Serum Ig A - is monomer and found in serum

Secretory Ig A - dimer, Two monomer units are joined together by a glycopeptide - J Chain

Contain glycine rich polypeptide secretory component which protect Ig A from denaturation by bacterial proteases.'

Secretory component is produced by mucosal or glandular epithelial cells.

Ig A1 - predominant Ig A

Ig A2 - predominant secretory Ig A

IgA has major role in local immunity in respiratory tract and gastro intestinal tract.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option B) IgM → Incorrect
    • IgM exists as a pentamer, not a dimer.
    • It is the first antibody produced in an immune response.
    • Strong agglutination and complement activation properties.
  • (Option C) IgD → Incorrect
    • IgD exists as a monomer.
    • It is mainly found on B-cell surfaces, acting as a receptor.
    • It plays a minor role in immune responses.
  • (Option D) IgE → Incorrect
    • IgE exists as a monomer.
    • It is involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections.
    • It binds to mast cells and basophils, triggering histamine release.

Key Takeaways:

  • IgA is the only immunoglobulin that forms a dimer (in secretions).
  • IgM is a pentamer, while IgD and IgE exist as monomers.
  • Secretory IgA is the main antibody protecting mucosal surfaces (GI, respiratory, and urogenital tracts).

questions.text: The Immunoglobulin structure (Pentamer) shown in the figure belongs to which class of antibody?
questions.solution:
Ig M is pentameric immunoglobulin with five - four peptide subunits.

The subunits are joined by j chian.

J chain is found in Ig A and Ig M

Ig M is the most efficient antibody which fixes complement by classical pathways.

Ig M is elevated in primary immune response.

Ig M in transported through placenta, so presence of Ig M indicates intrauterine infection.

Incorrect Answer Explanations:

  • (Option A) IgA → Incorrect
    • IgA is found as a monomer in serum and a dimer in secretions (secretory IgA).
    • It plays a key role in mucosal immunity.
  • (Option C) IgD → Incorrect
    • IgD is a monomer, mainly present on B-cell surfaces as a receptor.
    • It has a minor role in immune responses.
  • (Option D) IgE → Incorrect
    • IgE is a monomer.
    • It is involved in allergic reactions and parasite defense.
    • It binds to mast cells and basophils, triggering histamine release.

Key Takeaways:

  • IgM is the only pentameric antibody, making it highly effective in complement activation and agglutination.
  • Presence of IgM in a newborn suggests an intrauterine infection.
  • IgA (dimer), IgD (monomer), and IgE (monomer) do not form pentamers.
